docs.lead_paragraph: Finding a vivid way to emphasize Pope John Paul II's opposition to abortion, Roman Catholic leaders here introduced him today to 3-year-old twins who had been joined at birth and were later separated. As each little girl was held above his lap while he sat in a thronelike chair on the altar of a makeshift outdoor cathedral, he stroked her face. Then the girls' mother, Melita Tothova, who had lifted them toward the pope, kneeled and kissed his hand.

headline.main: A Frail Pope Meets Slovak Twins in an Anti-Abortion Gesture

docs.abstract: Roman Catholic officials dramatize church's opposition to abortion by having Pope John Paul II appear at outdoor Mass in Slovakia with three-year-old girls who were joined at birth and later separated (S)
docs.snippet: Finding a vivid way to emphasize Pope John Paul II's opposition to abortion, Roman Catholic leaders here introduced him today to 3-year-old twins who had been joined at birth and were later separated.    As each little girl was held above his lap...

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH the economy uncertain and many companies looking to keep down costs and pare their employment rolls, growing numbers of workers are filing charges of pregnancy discrimination. Lawyers specializing in labor law as well as leaders of women's advocacy groups around the country say they have detected an increase in pregnancy discrimination cases in recent years. And at the federal level, claims of discriminatory treatment during pregnancy filed with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission have increased 39 percent over the last 10 years, to 4,714 in 2002. That is a tiny fraction of the number of working women, but Jocelyn C. Frye, director of legal and public policy for the National Partnership for Women and Families, a nonprofit advocacy group for women in the workplace, said that this was because pregnancy discrimination cases rarely reach the federal level. Many complaints are handled by state agencies, settled or simply dropped.

headline.main: Pregnant Workers Filing More Complaints of Bias

docs.abstract: Lawyers specializing in labor law say there is increase in pregnancy discrimination cases in recent years; at federal level, claims have increased 39 percent over last 10 years, but National Partnership for Women and Families says pregnancy discrimination cases rarely reach federal level with complaints being handled at state agencies, settled or dropped; photo (M)
docs.snippet: WITH the economy uncertain and many companies looking to keep down costs and pare their employment rolls, growing numbers of workers are filing charges of pregnancy discrimination.     Lawyers specializing in labor law as well as leaders of women's...

docs.lead_paragraph: My daughter Alena was born on July 20, and I am lucky I was there. I'm a Democratic Texas state senator from Houston. Things started heating up in Austin early on in my wife Licia's pregnancy, but by her ninth month, they had reached a boiling point. In the Texas Senate, you need two-thirds of the members to agree to bring up a bill. Ten Democrats and one Republican voted to not bring up redistricting. That should have ended it -- until our lieutenant governor changed the two-thirds rule. The House members had broken quorum in May by fleeing Texas, so my fellow Democratic senators and I decided to follow suit. I just hoped we wouldn't go before the birth of my fourth child. My wife and I have a 4-year-old son, Leland, and each of us has a daughter from a prior marriage. Nicole is 15 and Maria is 9. I started hinting to my wife that I might have to leave. While she has always been supportive of my work, this time she was, shall we say, chilly. On Friday, July 18, Licia went into the hospital, and I rushed home from Austin to be with her. It was a false alarm. Then a few days later, sure enough, the baby was born. Still, I had come home that weekend knowing I needed to pack my bag. I wasn't sure when exactly or for how long I'd be gone. My wife understood. She is Jesse Jackson Jr.'s former chief of staff, and her father was the head of the N.A.A.C.P. in Cincinnati. Once in a while in politics, you have to believe in something strongly enough that you're willing to make sacrifices.
docs.abstract: Lives column by Texas State Sen Rodney Ellis describes stresses on himself and his family when he and other Democratic senators fled state to prevent legislative action on Republican redistricting bill (M)
docs.snippet: My daughter Alena was born on July 20, and I am lucky I was there. I'm a Democratic Texas state senator from Houston. Things started heating up in Austin early on in my wife Licia's pregnancy, but by her ninth month, they had reached a boiling point....

docs.lead_paragraph: Clarence Aguirre is the skinnier, more boisterous twin, the one who flips his brother, shimmies to music and, in pictures, is usually grinning. Carl is more serious, a bit reserved -- though not averse to yanking Clarence's hair from time to time. But they have seen each other only in a mirror.

headline.main: Surgeons Meet Conjoined Twins: One Quiet, the Other With a Grin

docs.abstract: Surgeons at Children's Hospital in Bronx meet Clarence and Carl Aguirre, 17-month-old conjoined twins from Philippines, whom they will try to separate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pope John Paul II arrived here today to beseech Slovaks not to follow Western Europe's drift from Christianity, but he could not deliver that message in his own strained, trembling voice. As he made his opening remarks at an airport greeting ceremony here, he garbled his words, seemed to lose his place in the text and stopped after just a few minutes. An aide took the text from him and handed it to another Vatican official to read.

headline.main: Aide Steps In for Pope at an Airport to Finish a Garbled Speech to Slovaks

docs.abstract: Pope John Paul II arrives in Bratislava, Slovakia, but is unable to complete his opening remarks at airport greeting ceremony; pope, who is 83 and in poor health, slumps in his chair, looking pale and exhausted; this is first time in over year that his frailties have been obvious cause of his abandoning prepared text during foreign trip; it raises fresh questions about his health; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Pope John Paul II arrived here today to beseech Slovaks not to follow Western Europe's drift from Christianity, but he could not deliver that message in his own strained, trembling voice.    As he made his opening remarks at an airport greeting...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a bid to prevent the widespread practice of aborting female fetuses to prevent the birth of unwanted daughters, the Supreme Court directed federal and state governments to enforce laws banning ultrasound scans for the prenatal determination of sex. The practice has left some states with a gender imbalance. The 2002 census found that in the states of Haryana and Punjab the ratio of girls below the age of 6 had fallen to 90 for every 100 boys, from 95 in 1991. In Haryana there were 86 females for 100 males, compared with a national average of 93 females for every 100 males.

headline.main: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ban On Prenatal Scans Ordered Enforced

docs.abstract: Indian Supreme Court directs federal and state governments to enforce laws banning use of prenatal tests to determine child's sex; recent census figures show significant changes in gender balance in Punjab and Haryana states; shift is attributed to prenatal tests and aborting female offspring (S)
docs.snippet: In a bid to prevent the widespread practice of aborting female fetuses to prevent the birth of unwanted daughters, the Supreme Court directed federal and state governments to enforce laws banning ultrasound scans for the prenatal determination of...

docs.lead_paragraph: After years of suffering with stress urinary incontinence, an annoying and embarrassing disorder that forced her to shun her favorite activities and think twice even before lifting a heavy bag of groceries, Gloria Rose of Wellesley, Mass., wants the world of fellow sufferers to know there are ways to curtail this distressing problem. Six months ago Ms. Rose underwent a relatively simple operation -- installation of a vaginal sling to support her urethra against increases in abdominal pressure -- to correct the problem that afflicts as many as one woman in three and a much smaller number of men.

headline.main: Back in the Saddle, Confident and Diaperless

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column shares success story of 56-year-old Gloria Rose, who has overcome her stress urinary incontinence through relatively new surgical procedure known as tension-free vaginal tape sling placement; condition is often not diagnosed because women are too embarrassed to discuss it with their doctors and treatment options remain somewhat unknown even to medical professionals; factors, some of which include having been pregnant, age, obesity and smoking, can increase chances of becoming incontinent; nurse practitioner Diane K Newman, University of Pennsylvania division of urology, writes in American Journal of Nursing that majority of cases of incontinence could be improved through strenghthening of pelvic floor muscles; Kegel exercisesare discussed; procedures and surgeries available to help treat incontinence are enumerated; drawing (M)
